JOCARROLL DEPOT LOCAL REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY PROJECT AND FISCAL YEAR 2019 WORK PLAN ABSTRACT THE LRA IS SEEKING A GRANT FROM OEA TO PERFORM CRITICAL INVESTIGATIONS THAT WILL DEFINE AND REFINE REQUIREMENTS TO ENABLE DECISION MAKING RELATED TO DEVELOPING A REUSE PLAN FOR PARCEL 20. THE CRITICAL STUDIES INCLUDE BATHYMETRY, DREDGING, AND HYDRAULICS SILTING, NAVIGATIONAL CHANNELS, DREDGE SPOIL DISPOSAL, WATER FLOW, VOLUMES ADJACENT, UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF PARCEL 20. IT IS ANTICIPATED THE BATHYMETRY, DREDGING, AND HYDRAULICS WILL TAKE APPROXIMATELY 3 TO 6 MONTHS FOR A FINAL REPORT TRANSITION PLANNING A TRANSITION PLAN FOR THE ANALYSIS OF POTENTIAL TRANSFER OF THE OVERSIGHT AND MANAGEMENT OF ONGOING JOCARROL DEPOT LRA RESPONSIBILITIES TO THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI INTERNATIONAL PORT DISTRICT ANALYSIS TO INCLUDE ASSETS AND LIABILITIES, RECOMMENDATIONS FOR LEADERSHIP TRANSITION AND STRUCTURE, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A DRAFT FINANCIAL PLAN MOVING FORWARD THE LRA IS ALSO REQUESTING ADMINISTRATIVE AND CONTRACTUAL SUPPORT TO ASSIST IN THE CONTINUED REDEVELOPMENT OF THE FORMER SAVANNA ARMY DEPOT PERFORMING THESE CRITICAL INVESTIGATIONS WILL ALLOW THE LRA TO ACCEPT THIS PARCEL THEREFORE ALLOWING THE ARMY TO MOVE FORWARD WITH THEIR DISPOSAL PROCESS, TRANSFERRING APPROXIMATELY 132 ACRES OFF ARMY LEDGERS AND SAVING DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE RESOURCES. IT ALSO PROVIDES THE POTENTIAL FOR PROFOUND IMPACTS AND BENEFITS TO THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES. ACCESS TO THIS PARCEL MAY ALLOW THE COMMUNITY TO RESHAPE THE OUTCOME OF WHAT HAS BEEN A VERY SLOW AND PAINFUL CLEANUP PROCESS AND PROVIDE FOR A LARGER DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITY. THESE INVESTIGATIONS ARE REQUIRED TO UNDERSTAND THE BATHYMETRY, HYDRAULICS AND DREDGING CONCERNS THAT REDEVELOPMENT OF PARCEL 20 REQUIRES. REVIEW OF ARMY PREPARED WETLAND AND THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES REPORTS WILL ALSO BE REQUIRED. THE LRA AND ARMY ARE CURRENTLY COLLABORATING REGARDING ADDITIONAL ARMY STUDIES PERTAINING TO ADDITIONAL WETLANDS AND THREATENED&ENDANGERED SPECIES INFORMATION.

THE HORSHAM LAND REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY HLRA IS REQUESTING CONTINUED OEA FINANCIAL GRANT ASSISTANCE TO SUPPORT THE HLRA TO ACCOMPLISH THEIR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES RELATING TO THE DECLARATION OF SURPLUS PROPERTY BY THE U.S. NAVY RELATING TO THE NAS JRB WILLOW GROVE FACILITY UNDER BRAC 2005. IN JULY 2014 THE NAVY ADVISED THE HLRA THAT A NEWLY IDENTIFIED ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN WOULD IMPACT THEIR ABILITY TO TRANSFER PROPERTY PER THE INFORMAL SCHEDULE PREVIOUSLY DISCUSSED. THE ISSUE RELATES TO THE PRESENCE OF PER AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES PFAS IN THE GROUNDWATER ON AND IN THE VICINITY OF THE FORMER BASE. THE FULL IMPACT ON THE SCHEDULE FOR PROPERTY TRANSFER IS UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME. THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCYS EPA PFAS ACTION PLAN STATES THE EPA IS MOVING FORWARD WITH HOW BEST TO DESIGNATE PFOA AND PFOS AS CERCLA HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES USING ONE OF THE AVAILABLE STATUTORY MECHANISMS. DESPITE THIS STATEMENT AS OF THIS DATE NO STANDARDS FOR PFAS SUBSTANCES IN SOIL SURFACE WATER OR SEDIMENTS HAVE BEEN ISSUED. THIS DELAY IS CONTINUING THE UNCERTAINTIES FACED BY THE NAVY IN DEVELOPING A REMEDIAL SOLUTION TO THE PFAS ISSUE AT THE FORMER NAS JRB WILLOW GROVE. DESPITE THESE UNCERTAINTIES THE NAVY IS PROCEEDING WITH ACTIONS WHICH MAY AFFECT THEIR ABILITY TO ISSUE A FINDING OF SUITABILITY TO TRANSFER FOST DOCUMENT AND RESULT IN THE RESUMPTION OF ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CONVEYANCE NEGOTIATIONS. THE NAVY ANTICIPATES THESE ACTIONS AS WELL AS LAND USE CONTROLS AND DEED RESTRICTIONS WILL ALLOW THEM TO WORK WITH THE REGULATORS TOWARDS AGREEMENT THAT REDEVELOPMENT CAN PROCEED. OEA TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL SUPPORT WILL PERMIT THE CURRENT HLRA STAFF TO CONTINUE OPERATIONS AND PROVIDE INPUT DURING THE NAVYS INVESTIGATION OF AND REMEDIAL RESPONSE TO THE PFAS CONTAMINATION ISSUE AS WELL AS CONTINUE WORKING WITH A POTENTIAL MASTER DEVELOPER CANDIDATE IN DEVELOPING A MASTER DEVELOPER AGREEMENT. IT WILL ALSO PERMIT CONTINUING EFFORTS REGARDING PUBLIC RELATIONS REGARDING THE FUTURE REDEVELOPMENT.

THE MIDCOAST REGIONAL REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY MRRA IS THE OEA RECOGNIZED IMPLEMENTATION LOCAL REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY FOR REDEVELOPMENT OF THE FORMER BRUNSWICK NAVAL AIR STATION. THE MIDCOAST REGIONAL REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY A COMPONENT UNIT OF THE STATE OF MAINE IS A MUNICIPAL CORPORATION CREATED BY MAINE LAW 5 MRSA 13083 G AND CHARGED WITH THE RESPONSIBILITY TO ACQUIRE AND MANAGE PROPERTY AT THE FORMER NAVAL AIR STATION BRUNSWICK NAS BRUNSWICK AND THE TOPSHAM ANNEX AND TO FACILITATE THE RAPID REDEVELOPMENT OF PROPERTIES IN ORDER TO RECOVER FROM ECONOMIC AND EMPLOYMENT LOSS AS RESULT OF BASE CLOSURE DECISION IN 2005. THE FIRST MEETING OF THE MRRA BOARD OF TRUSTEES WAS HELD ON SEPTEMBER 27 2007. THE GOAL OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP AN AMENDMENT TO MRRAS REUSE MASTER PLAN TO INCORPORATE AN ADDITIONAL 144 ACRES OF EDC LAND ON THE WEST SIDE OF BRUNSWICK LANDING THAT HAD EARLIER BEEN REQUESTED BY BOWDOIN COLLEGE. OEA SUPPORT WILL ALLOW MRRA TO IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE LAND USES FOR THAT AREA AND DEVELOP DRAFT AMENDMENTS TO THE TOWNS COMPREHENSIVE PLAN AND ZONING ORDINANCE TO PROPOSE TO THE TOWN OF BRUNSWICK TO IMPLEMENT THE NEW LAND USES.

THE COLUMBIA DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY (CDA) IS USING OEA GRANT ASSISTANCE FOR CONTINUED PLANNING AND REDEVELOPMENT OF THE 19,729-ACRE UMATILLA CHEMICAL DEPOT (UMCD) LOCATED IN UMATILLA COUNTY AND MORROW COUNTY, OREGON. THE UMCD OFFICIALLY CLOSED ON AUGUST 1, 2012, AND THE CDA IS PLANNING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE FORMER DEPOT IN ACCORDANCE WITH THEIR COMPLETED REDEVELOPMENT PLAN. THE CDA IS COMPRISED OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM UMATILLA COUNTY, MORROW COUNTY, THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE UMATILLA INDIAN RESERVATION, PORT OF MORROW, AND PORT OF UMATILLA. THE GRANT PROVIDES FOR THE FOLLOWING: 1. CONTINUED OPERATIONS SUPPORT FOR THE CDA OFFICE. THE CDA IS THE DESIGNATED IMPLEMENTING LOCAL REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY. 2. LEGAL ASSISTANCE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CONVEYANCE (EDC) TRANSACTIONAL DOCUMENTS AND RELATED MATTERS, AND FOR ISSUES RELATED TO ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS AND LIABILITY ASSESSMENT ASSOCIATED WITH THE EDC. THE CDA HOPES TO NEGOTIATE AND EXECUTE AN EDC WITH THE ARMY FOR THE TRANSFER OF AN ESTIMATED 12,300 ACRES, INCLUDING EASEMENTS, FROM THE ARMY TO THE CDA BY LATE 2019 OR EARLY 2020.

OPERATIONAL BRAC ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CONVEYANCE EDC NEGOTIATIONS AND ENVIRONMENTAL LEGAL SERVICESA UDIT SERVICES THIS GRANT WILL ADVANCE THE ARMY S MANDATE TO RETURN NEARLY 16 000 ACRES OF THE PCD BACK TO LOCAL CONTROL AND REMOVE THEM FROM THE ARMYS ACTIVE BASE INVENTORY

THE GRANT ENABLES THE RIVERBANK LOCAL REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY TO SUSTAIN THE REDEVELOPMENT EFFORTS ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION AND TRANSFER OF THE FORMER RIVERBANK ARMY AMMUNITION PLANT REAL PROPERTY WHICH IS PARAMOUNT TO THE US ARMY S COMMITMENT AND EFFORTS TO REDIRECT SCARCE RESOURCES TO CRITICAL MISSION READINESS REQUIREMENTS FOCUSED ON ENHANCING THE ARMY S RESILIENCY AND LETHALITY.
